bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 17, 1949

div1.p: Truby commends Hench on his work with cortisone in treating rheumatic fever, and encloses two communications he has received from men who were at Columbia Barracks during the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, November 17, 1949
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
Nov. 17/49
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
I have your recent letter
with a copy of one you wrote to Gen.
Kean about your trip East. I was so
glad to know that you stood the trip
so well and that you are feeling so
well. I infer from your remarks
about McCoy that he has Gen. Wood's
diary. If so, it should have much
about Reed & his work. It will probably
consist of concise and most valuable facts.

I do hope you can see it. In case
you see Gen. Mc C. kindly remember
me to him. I knew him in Cuba
and also in the P.I.

The Y.F. work is interesting and pleasant
so that you will probably be glad of a
change from hormones and these terrible
rheumatic stories. I have just seen the
article by S.B. Lal in the American Weekly (Nov. 13)
re the 15 yr old girl with acute rheumatic
fever and your treatment of her with Cortisone
in March '49. She was treated until May 4 and
has remained without symptoms since
Quite wonderful, and means more hope for
Ac
Tr
the young and more benefit to humanity
as a whole then the coare of the chronic
cases. To me this is the most wonderful
of all medical discoveries in this century and
all preceeding ones-too. Bravo!

Recently two of the men of the old
Ch Columbia Bks. Detatchment have written
me. One was from one of our bright
young clerks in the office. Will inclose one
of his recent letters. His name is Tate.

The other man is quite Senile, and
wants to get on the “Roll of Honor” because
he was ordered to report to Major Reed. But,
as I pointed out to him, he did not
take the test. He was simply ordered
to duty at the camp. I had copies made
from the original printed order and am
sending you a copy. Perhaps you already have
one. I think you wrote me once that you
have the order of Ames for duty with the
Reed Bd. and that order is on the same paper.

Tate might be of use to you, but Morris
is hopeless judging from his letters.

Thanks for the Brooklyn Hospital Journal
which came today.

All of us are well and we send our
best wishes to you and yours.

My pen has a bad point, hence this bad
writing.
